item.item_label: Personal protective equipment (PPE) and face coverings
How to wash your hands the right way?
What are the symptoms of Covid-19?

screen.Content:
The following elearning has been produced by Open eLMS Creator in response to the Coronavirus pandemic. Please use is freely, embedding it on your website or installing on your company’s Learning Management System.

All we ask is to consider Open eLMS the next time you need any elearning.

screen_id.keywords: Work, Sky, City, Skyline, Building, Board, White, Presentation

screen.Content:
Welcome to this learning session about Coronavirus. In this course we shall address:

• What is Covid-19?

• How to protect yourself and others?

• What is self-isolation and why is it important?

This module will take 20 minutes and there will be a few quick questions at the end to check how you’ve got on.

What is a coronavirus?

Coronaviruses are a family of viruses which cause disease in animals. Sometimes, as in this case, a virus can mutate and jump from animals to humans and cause infection.

This coronavirus has been named Covid-19, and since it first appeared in China, has now spread to over 110 countries around the globe.

screen_id.keywords: Help, Desk, Person, Consultation, Advice, Silhouette, Office, Work

screen.Content: There are many misconceptions surrounding the Covid-19 virus. Press below to learn more - knowing the truth could stop you getting infected and save lives.

It is mutating!

It is a common belief that Covid-19 is mutating into a more deadly strain.

Viruses mutate all the time but there is currently no evidence that any new mutations are more or less dangerous than what has gone on before.

It is no more dangerous than winter flu?

Currently the WHO estimates approximately a 1% fatality rate.

This would make Covid-19 about 10 times more deadly than seasonal flu, which is estimated to kill between 290,000 and 650,000 people a year globally. Since there is no vaccine this makes the disease particularly dangerous.

It only kills the old

Regardless of your age, you have a responsibility to society to not spread the disease. It is true to say that the older you get, the more chance you have of succumbing to the disease.

It is also true that those with an underlying health condition or health workers (who have a higher exposure to the virus) are also at greater risk.

It’s largely spread through contaminated surfaces

Good hygiene is important to prevent the virus being transmitted from surfaces, but this does seem to be relatively rare.

Hospital guidelines for winter flu define exposure as being within six feet of an infected person who sneezes or coughs for 15 minutes or longer. For this reason sharing a flight, or similar confined space seems to be a common method of infection.

A vaccine could be ready within a few months

To prepare a vaccine is a monumental task and releasing an untested vaccine could cause side effects far worse than the disease.

It is true to say trials started for a vaccine in Seattle, Washington in March 2020 but do not expect a vaccine this year - mid 2021 would be more realistic.

I should stockpile goods at home?

If you fear Covid-19 will lead to a food shortage, then panic buying and stockpiling food will potentially create the problem that you are afraid of.

It is highly unlikely that food delivery services will stop and the government has made preparations in case of this emergency. Covid-19 is not deadly enough to completely prevent food getting through to you.

Hot weather will kill the virus

It has been shown that this is largely untrue. Hot weather causes people to be outdoors and not so often in close proximity.

Yet global spikes in cases of the disease have been shown in even the hottest places (e.g. summer in Arizona).

How can we stop it?

Most viruses are transmitted in small droplets of water which are expelled during coughs and sneezes. The best way to prevent coronavirus is to effectively capture coughs and sneezes.

Evidence has also emerged that is may float in the air through aerosol transmission caused by shouting or singing.
The virus can also live on contaminated surfaces. For these reasons regular handwashing and cleaning of surfaces is also important.

screen.Section: Personal protective equipment (PPE) and face coverings
screen.Content: If you want to wear a face covering you should do so. Research has shown that masks have had great success in reducing transmission of the disease, particularly in enclosed spaces.
screen.Content_1: Wearing a mask should not affect your attitude to social distancing or hygiene however.

screen.Content:
Indeed now it is mandatory in many jurisdictions to wear face coverings in public.

It is vital that you follow your local authorities advice on the use of masks.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water for 20 seconds or use hand sanitiser before putting a face covering on, and before and after removing it.
When wearing a face covering, avoid touching your face or face covering, as you could contaminate them with germs from your hands.
Change your face covering if it becomes damp or if you’ve touched it.
Change and wash your face covering daily.
If the material is washable, wash in line with the manufacturer’s instructions. If it’s not washable, dispose of it carefully in your usual waste.

Countries such as China, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, Thailand and Taiwan have had marked success in reducing the transmission of the disease. These countries have had a high prevalence of mask wearing.

The world has now woken up to the importance of face coverings In many countries their use has now become mandatory, leaving a legal, as well as moral, obligation for you to protect yourself and others from this deadly disease.

You can make face-coverings at home - see this link for guidance.

screen_id.keywords: Work, Sky, City, Skyline, Building, Board, White, Presentation

screen.Section: How to wash your hands the right way?
screen.Content: According to the World Health Organisation, to wash your hands properly should take about as long as singing “Happy Birthday” twice.
Following the NHS video advice below to ensure your hands are washed properly ...

There are some things you can do now to help prevent the spread of Covid-19 when you do come into contact with people.

Press the next button below to see the steps you can take...

Avoid Shaking Hands

You should avoid shaking hands and kissing people on the cheek.

Approach people with a fist pump or an outstretched elbow. Make this the new normal!

Avoid touching your face

Touching your face causes the transmission of any virus from a contaminated surface into the eyes or mouth.

Identify triggers such as a runny nose or urge to sneeze which cause you to touch your face. Make sure you have a tissue close by, it's better to use that than to touch your face with your bare hands.

Follow government advice

This is particularly relevant for calls for social isolation and self isolation.

Such measures can stop the virus in a very short period of time if everybody acts together.

screen.Section: What are the symptoms of Covid-19?
screen.Content:
OK - so lets say you have taken the necessary precautions, but regardless you fear you may have contracted the virus.

Let's first look at the symptoms you should be aware of that could indicate you may have Covid-19.

Symptoms

Symptoms related to Covid-19 include:

• Fever and abnormal tiredness

• Coughing and sneezing

• Breathing difficulties

• Muscle pain

Close contact

If you have been within 2 metres of someone diagnosed with Covid-19 for 15 minutes or more, it would be classed as “close contact” and you should be extremely vigilant for symptoms.

Similarly, if you have tested positive for Covid-19, you should make sure all of those you have been in close contact with are notified by the health authorities.

Where to get help?

If you are either experiencing symptoms or have been in close contact with someone who has the virus then you should contact the relevant health authorities in your country.

DO NOT go to a GP surgery, pharmacy or hospital.

Do call emergency services should there be a medical emergency.

screen_id.keywords: City, Travel, Holiday, Business, World, Housing, Comunity, Lights, Night

screen.Content:
Social distancing involves asking people to stop non-essential contact with others and avoid all unnecessary travel.

Social distancing basically means trying to avoid contact with other people.
In the UK for example social distancing has been encouraged by closing social venues such as pubs, clubs and theatres; also non-essential shops have been closed.
Avoid unnecessary travel.

People should start working from home wherever possible. Employees should get assistance from their employers to manage this.

People can go to work if they cannot do their work from home.
It is also wise for people in at-risk groups to stay at home for 12 weeks. This affects pregnant women, people aged over 70 and those with underlying health conditions.

screen_id.keywords: Building, House, Safety, Office, Door, Work

screen.Content:
Self Isolation

If one person in a household starts to display flu-like symptoms - defined as a fever of above 37.8C° or a persistent cough - that person must self-isolate and can only leave the house 7 days from when the symptoms started.

Everyone else living there must stay at home for 14 days since it takes a while to develop symptoms.
To self-isolate means staying at home - do not go to work, school or other public places (including shops, restaurants or similar) and avoid public transport or taxies.

Keep yourself away from others within your home, in a well ventilated room unless absolutely necessary.

Do ask for help should you need it for groceries, other shopping or medication.

Do not share towels, toiletries or other similar items.

If you cannot use a separate bathroom, you should use the shared one last, and if able, clean it thoroughly after.
Avoid using the kitchen at the same time as other people in your home, and eat meals in your room.
Having friends, family or delivery drivers drop off supplies to you is okay, but you should not have any visitors. Ask for all deliveries to be left on your doorstep.

Any rubbish/trash that you have been in contact with should be double-bagged and kept.

If you are subsequently tested positive, the health authorities will instruct you what to do with it.

If you are not self-employed, then you should still get paid as per the rules and regulations of your country for sick pay.

Many countries have made emergency arrangements in this area, so if you are unsure of the current situation on this matter, contact someone from HR.

As an example in the UK, emergency rules have dictated that workers will be paid statutory sick pay of £94.25 per week from the first day of illness.

Recent legislation has also allowed for the furloughing of staff allowing employees to temporarily lay off their staff for 80% of the standard pay or £2,500 per month (whichever is the lower amount.)

Again in the UK, if you need to care for a relative, or your child’s school is closed and you must look after them, your employer must give you time off, but it may be unpaid.

It is important that any children are not looked after by elderly relatives as they are particularly at risk.

screen_id.keywords: Quiz, Questionnaire, Question, Exam, Multiple Choice

screen.Content: Please answer these questions and get as many right as possible.

settings.Retake_Test: You have reached the end of the test.
settings.No_Issues: You have got 100%, no further action is required.
settings.Few_Issues: You have got very few questions wrong, there is no cause for immediate concern.
settings.Some_Issues: You have got some answers wrong, you may wish to retake the test.
settings.Many_Issues: You have got many questions wrong, we strongly recommend you redo the training.

screen.Content_1:
Congratulations you have now completed the course on Covid-19. You should now know:

• What is Covid-19?

• How to protect yourself and others?

• What is self-isolation and why is it important?

screen.Content: Thank you for using the course. Please check at our website for updates in the elearning as this course is updated with any major changes with this global pandemic.
